svcsubproc.title: Electronic Gauges
svcsubproc.para: The electronic gauges are the speedometer, tachometer, and voltmeter. The speedometer and tachometer are 4-pin gauges and are microprocessor driven gauges. The microprocessor is factory programmed to operate from data link signals generated by the Electronic Control Module (ECM). The voltmeter is a 2-pin gauge, and operates by voltage supplied by the battery and charging system.
These gauges have pin sockets located in the rear. These sockets mate with pin connectors in the gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Electrical Gauges
svcsubproc.para: The 3-pin gauges in this group operate on 12 volts and are connected directly to the gauge sender. Gauges in this group include engine oil temperature, axle temperature, engine water temperature, fuel, and transmission temperature.
The exhaust temperature (pyrometer) gauge, also included in this section, is an electrical gauge, but has its own control module (signal amplifier).
The electrical gauges have pin sockets located in the rear. These sockets mate with pin connectors in the gauge cluster.

svcsubproc.title: Mechanical Gauges
svcsubproc.para: The air pressure, oil pressure, transmission oil pressure, and air application gauges are all mechanical. The gauge movement is caused by pressure from the affected system.

These gauges are of the quick connect type. The gauges have a straight tip with an O-ring seal. The hub of the gauge case in which the tip fits has bayonet grooves for locking the gauge in place. The gauge cluster has the quick connect socket fittings. These have Schrader valves in them which close when the gauge is removed and prevents the gauge lines from leaking or depressurizing.
The air restriction gauge is also mechanical. The gauge movement is caused by the pressure drop across it. The vacuum inside the air cleaner housing provides this pressure.
